How did you do it? The truck dropped me off at the Deflagration vid:(

I just  saw this one. Tie to the fallen one slightly above the first prop tree (tall stump), run rope away from house to pull tree off of "stump" without trunk coming closer to house. (A come-along or block and tackle would come in handy here) once you get it off of the first "stump" you may have to figure what to do all over again, because trees bound by other trees don't always behave as it seems they should. I had an 8-inch pine suddenly come unbound and swing across both shins like a baseball bat. I was very fortunate to just walk around with pain for quite some time, it could have been much worse. Take it one obstacle at a time. +mrkazman we call these widowmakers here in the states also. @SmarterEveryDay I know this is an old video and you have already taken care of the problem, but it seems that you maybe still haven't posted the "how we did it" video, or at least haven't added the link. I would like to see what y'all ended up figuring out.

I looked at it for one seconds and recognised it. In australia we have a name for these little tree-sex organisations. they are widow makers.
For every new one, you have to be very careful, you don't know what kinds of tension are being held in the structure until you cut it, and it kicks out in a random direction like the wrath of a god.
One word: Tanerite!

As a Canadian, I know how to fall a tree when it is hung up. Notch the two hung up trees in the direction you want them to fall, then notch a third heavy tree to fall on them to cause all three to go the same direction. You don't want to fully cut the base of the damaged trees, because the pressure could split the tree in half causing a kick back.
That's a statics problem..  3 dimensional statics problem..  I'm having flashbacks to engineering coursework..  aaaagh nooooo

i know its kinda late for this comment but from the angle that i was able to see, i would have had the guys tie rope around the base of the tree by the house, have them pull it away from the house as you cut even closer to the base. you should be standing on the side closest to the house, that way you dont get hit by the tree. if im right, the tree you should cut down will finish taking down the other tree its balancing on.

wqhat cuneiform2012 said was my first thoughts... tie roaps to both trees attached to car\truck bumpers and pull slowly in opposite directions to dislodge both trees. with everyone far out of the way.  we did did this on the roof of my house in the May 3rd 1999 oklahoma city tornados with 100" tow straps... Ya, we lost our home in that one.  but had fun pulling the house apart!!
Free the root ball from the horizontal Balanced tree, then with the aid of a long cable leader pull the base away from the trailer using a comalong (cable puller) until it pops off the fulcrum tree.

If I were you, I'd wrap up the tree that has derooted and leaning on the broken tree with a rope attached to a truck and drive away from the trailer. That should yank it out of balance and allow it to fall to the ground on the opposite side of the tree to the trailer. Making sure it doesn't damage the home. If you left enough slack in the rope/chain combo and keep everyone far away, you wouldn't have to worry about anyone or anything being hurt. I'd just be happy there are no power lines close.
wrap a rope around it and pull it down with the truck...

I'm no lumberjack, but if the bigger tree balanced on the other half tree is not jammed by other trees I would try to pull it away from the house, while making sure the half broken tree didn't swing in the opposite direction (making the half tree to fall into the same direction would be the best)... good luck :/
some type of brain puzzle or somethin bo
No matter what you do, step one should be to cut off the power, water, and gas to the trailer....not that I lack confidence, just sayin'
wrap rope around the fallen tree thats being propped up and pull away from the trailor.. attach it to an ATV or tractor or something..
I would climb the straddled tree and start wacking away at the fallen tree one branch at a time.  The goal would be to get as much pressure off the other trees without having a major weight shift.

If you have or can get a come-along, then your options open up a lot. I recommend climbing the felled tree and cutting off the top so that there is less mass to fall at once. Then, using the come-along, put tension on the tree that is being rested on. Cut partway through the tree until it starts creaking or just until it starts moving. Then apply pressure with the come-along until it falls. The trees should be stable enough to walk on if they survived the rest of the tornado like that.

Looks to my un-trained eye that a come-along winch might work, get far enough away and wench the tree off the tree while it is still around another tree. That would be my first guess. Wrap one end of the come-along around a tree for an anchor point and use a rope or tow strap around the fallen tree. Pull it off. If that don't work, set it all on fire with the dragon breath ammo.
